edponce commented on a change in pull request #9786:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/9786#discussion_r600542884



##########
File path: cpp/src/arrow/array/array_binary_test.cc
##########
@@ -301,14 +301,18 @@ class TestStringArray : public ::testing::Test {
     auto st2 = ValidateFull(1, {0, 4}, "\xf4\x90\x80\x80");
     // Single UTF8 character straddles two entries
     auto st3 = ValidateFull(2, {0, 1, 2}, "\xc3\xa9");
+    // Null characters in the string
+    auto st4 = ValidateFull(1, {0, 4}, "\0\0\0\0");

Review comment:
       You are right, this case is valid. The UTF-8 standard (https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3629) states that characters consisting of 1-byte range from 0-7F (Section 3). But a multibyte UTF-8 character will not contain NUL as a continuation byte, the encoding does not allows it.
   Valid: '\x00'
   Invalid: '\xe10080'




--

issuetype.description: A new feature of the product, which has yet to be developed.
issuetype.name: New Feature

fields.description:
We have "binary_length" but that doesn't handle UTF-8 the way we need for this. Example (from R):

{code}
> string <- "áéíóú"
> nchar(string)
[1] 5
> arrow:::call_function("binary_length", Scalar$create(string))
Scalar
10
{code}

cc [~maartenbreddels] [~apitrou] [~jorisvandenbossche]

comments.body: The {{binary_length}} was originally added as {{ascii_length}} in https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/7278/, as a simple (example) kernel, and indeed not yet meant to specifically handle unicode logical string size, I think. Having a proper UTF8 string length kernel would indeed be good (also needed for pandas' string methods).
I'll take it unless someone else feels strongly about it :)

We can leverage *utf8proc* which is already a dependency for some string operations in compute kernel. Specifically, use the *utf8proc_iterate* function (https://juliastrings.github.io/utf8proc/doc/utf8proc_8h.html#a48041dd763513b314763f5b40fad50b0)

I don't think we need {{utf8proc}}. Counting UTF8 characters is simply a matter of counting bytes with the upper bit cleared

(Python pseudocode:  {{utf8_length(bytestring) = sum((b < 0x80) for b in bytestring)}})
I have a utf8proc implementation, and will compare with pseudocode (I did find similar implementations while reading on UTF8).

Well, thinking more about it, simply checking against 0x80 also includes invalid sequences because not all sequences in that range are valid UTF8. Consider invalid bytes, invalid continuation bytes, invalid sequence, etc. utf8proc decodes taking into consideration these cases: https://github.com/JuliaStrings/utf8proc/blob/master/utf8proc.c#L124-L171
True, but utf8 data is supposed to be valid already. I don't think we need to care about invalid sequences here.
